Literature Review: The COVID-19 pandemic has presented unprecedented challenges to the global financial system, testing its resilience and adaptability in the face of severe economic disruption. This literature review examines the macro-financial stability during the COVID-19 crisis, focusing on the role of monetary and financial policies in mitigating the impact of the pandemic on financial markets and the real economy.The onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in early 2020 triggered a sharp economic downturn and initial financial market turmoil. However, the global financial system demonstrated remarkable resilience throughout the crisis. Goldstein and Xie (2021) argue that this resilience can be attributed to the swift and decisive actions taken by major central banks and financial regulators worldwide. Their study highlights how these interventions helped to stabilize financial markets and maintain the flow of credit to the real economy.One of the key factors contributing to financial stability during the pandemic was the rapid implementation of accommodative monetary policies by central banks. Cavallino and De Fiore (2020) analyze the monetary policy responses of major central banks during the initial phase of the COVID-19 crisis. They find that the unprecedented scale and speed of monetary easing, including interest rate cuts and large-scale asset purchases, played a crucial role in alleviating financial stress and supporting economic activity.The effectiveness of these monetary policy interventions was further enhanced by the complementary fiscal measures implemented by governments. Bianchi et al. (2020) examine the interaction between monetary and fiscal policies during the pandemic and conclude that the coordination between these policy domains was instrumental in preventing a more severe economic downturn and financial crisis.While the immediate policy responses were largely successful in stabilizing financial markets, the prolonged period of accommodative monetary policy has raised concerns about potential risks to financial stability in the longer term. Adrian and Natalucci (2020) discuss the unintended consequences of sustained monetary policy support, such as increased risk-taking behavior and the buildup of financial vulnerabilities. They emphasize the need for policymakers to carefully balance short-term stabilization objectives with longer-term financial stability considerations.The COVID-19 crisis has also highlighted the importance of macroprudential policies in enhancing the resilience of the financial system. Deghi et al. (2020) analyze the effectiveness of macroprudential measures implemented before and during the pandemic. Their findings suggest that countries with stronger macroprudential frameworks were better equipped to weather the financial shock caused by the pandemic.However, the crisis has also exposed some limitations in the current regulatory approach. Aikman et al. (2021) argue that the focus on regulating specific segments of the financial system, rather than taking a broader, system-wide approach, may have created regulatory arbitrage opportunities and contributed to the build-up of risks in less regulated sectors. They call for a more holistic approach to financial regulation that addresses interconnectedness and systemic risks across the entire financial system.The impact of the COVID-19 crisis on emerging market economies has been particularly severe, with many experiencing significant capital outflows and currency depreciation. Hofmann et al. (2020) examine the challenges faced by emerging market central banks during the pandemic and discuss the effectiveness of various policy tools, including foreign exchange interventions and capital flow management measures, in maintaining financial stability.Looking ahead, the COVID-19 crisis has underscored the need for continued vigilance and adaptation in maintaining macro-financial stability. Brunnermeier (2021) argues that the pandemic has accelerated existing trends, such as digitalization and the rise of non-bank financial intermediation, which may require new approaches to financial regulation and supervision. He emphasizes the importance of developing forward-looking policies that can address emerging risks and vulnerabilities in an increasingly complex and interconnected global financial system.In conclusion, the literature suggests that the resilience of the global financial system during the COVID-19 crisis can be largely attributed to the swift and coordinated policy responses of central banks and financial regulators. However, the crisis has also highlighted potential vulnerabilities and the need for a more comprehensive approach to financial stability. As the world emerges from the pandemic, policymakers face the challenge of unwinding emergency measures while safeguarding financial stability in an evolving economic and financial landscape.
